author: Tito Talao
title: Salud’s new system is ‘old’
text:
by Tito Talao
October 5, 2015 PBA president and chief executive Chito Salud believes the time has come for Gilas Pilipinas to settle for something more than silver linings in the international scene.
A different program, Salud says, could possibly be considered to help the national team overcome a second straight silver medal finish in the FIBA Asia Championship.
Chito Salud
“Lagi tayong silver under the present system for the past few years; we may have to tweak it a bit, fine-tune it, if we are to get over the hump,” says Salud, who was with the PBA delegation that cheered for the Philippine team in Changsha, China.
Salud’s recommendation is anchored on the formation of a pool of undrafted players as would be determined by the Samahang Basketbol ng Pilipinas and all its stakeholders, including the PBA.
“You could see that we really need the right mix and balance of young and matured players to be in a pool,” says Salud, for five seasons the PBA commissioner until he assumed the newly-created post in the restructured pro basketball organization a few months ago.
And that pool, Salud says, “will be playing and training for a long time under a system to be implemented by Gilas coach Tab Baldwin,” who the PBA executive heaped praises for what the national team had achieved in the Olympic qualifier in so short a period of time together.
“Ang galing ni Coach Tab,” says Salud. “Full game composure. He has a strategic mind that can tweak and adjust as the game flows; talagang virtual time adjustment.”
Salud adds: “He ought to be hired long-term for a long-term program.”
Should the pool be in place, depending on the kind of players the SBP and the PBA will agree on, it will then be “protected, reinforced and replenished” with pros as the competition requires, says the PBA top brass.
“Mas madali kesa sa pick-up system, di ba? Tapos dadgag na lang yung ating naturalized player,” says Salud, who also believes the SBP was on the right track with its Cadet program years ago.
“They planted the seeds back then. Who did they have na nagbunga na? (Marcio) Lassiter, (Chris) Lutz, Japeth (Aguilar), (Greg) Slaughter, (Mark) Barroca, right?” he says. “So idadagdag na lang, halimbawa, sina Paul Lee and (June Mar) Fajardo, even Calvin (Abueva). Maganda sana kung maituloy yon.”
He clarifies though: “I’m not saying it’s the only way however. But it’s perhaps something they can consider to start the ball rolling. Kasi we can’t repeat the same system over and over again and expect a different result, di ba? Pagod na yung mga fans sa silver. We want to look ahead and hurdle the silver block. We want a gold medal finish.”
With the format changes FIBA is set to implement starting 2017, which will see quarterly tournaments instead of one big regional meet for Asia, Salud says devising a new system in forming the national team has become even more imperative.
Quarterly FIBA tournaments would mean quarterly disruptions in the PBA season if the country’s top players are again to be recruited for international duty, a situation Salud doubts would be tenable to pro teams.
